content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-288-07-B |Item_parent=Hemorrhoidal pathology |Item_parent_short=Hemorrhoidal pathology |Rank=B |Title=Knowing the differential diagnosis of internal haemorrhoids |Description= |Rubric=Positive diagnosis |Contributors= |Order=7}} Cf: ''[[Differential diagnosis of external haemorrhoidal thrombosis 2C-288-DP-B02|2C-288-DP-B02]]'''' The main diagnostic difficulty lies in the "haemorrhoid offence": sufferers and the practitioners concerned attribute any proctological complaint a priori to haemorrhoids, whereas these non-specific complaints may be related to suppuration, an anal fissure or cancer. This highlights the need for a detailed semiological approach and a good clinical examination. In order to avoid being confused by a different symptomatology, the following summary table provides points of orientation in the event of acute pain. '''Table 1: etiological orientation according to anal pain''' {| class="wikitable" |What type? |What rhythm? |How long does it last? |But also .... |So I mention |- |Cooking |The saddle |One to two days |Prostatic edema and bleeding |Haemorrhoidal crisis |- |Intense pain |Touching/support |A few hours to a few days |Painful anal tumefaction, well-limited |External haemorrhoidal thrombosis |- |Burning |Bowel movement and long afterwards (hours) |Periods of several weeks |Bleeding |Anal fissure |- |Tension |Touch/support |Several hours and continuous, inflammatory |Painful swelling, poorly limited; dysuria |Abscess |- |Fingerprints |Before bowel movements |Several days |Seizures |Fecalome/ cancer |}

question.question: What is a common misconception or misunderstanding that could confuse the diagnosis of internal haemorrhoids?
question.option_a: Haemorrhoids are the only cause of anal pain.
question.option_b: Anal pain can be caused by a variety of conditions, including suppuration, anal fissures, or cancer.
question.option_c: A detailed semiological approach and good clinical examination are not necessary for diagnosing haemorrhoids.
question.option_d: Haemorrhoids are always accompanied by bleeding.
